According to the general news and GJP consensus.

The structure of this question is the problem. There seems almost no chance that any of the current area trade deals involving the USA or the EU will be ratified anytime soon because in the public mind negotiated trade deals equate to giving jobs to foreigners and/or setting up arbitration systems that give away sovereignty. So the average voter is convinced that a trade deal is a "bad thing". (What the average voter wants is a gun boat sent to the foreign country to force them to give us a sweet deal, as we did things in the 19th Century).   
However the question is will negotiations  be completed. Negotiations could be completed with an agreement that is likely to be ratified, Negotiations could be completed with an agreement that is unlikely to be ratified. Negotiations could be completed with no agreement at all.  With several big elections coming up in the next 15 months or so (US, French, German etc.) it is unknown which politicians would be in office when any TTIP agreement came up for ratification. Therefore completing negotiations in 2016 seems pointless because that would mean attempting to ratify an agreement that had been made under a different administration (certainly in the US and almost certainly in France). So it seems to me that it would be more productive to get as far with a TTIP agreement as possible this year, but leave the really difficult area for the next administration to struggle with. TTIP will be difficult sell, a TTIP agreement made by a previous administration, that started discussions when free trade sounded a "good thing", will be impossible to sell now that its viewed as a "bad thing". Who knows, in a couple of years time after Trumponomics and the freedom of Brexit have been shown to have some flaws, maybe an unfinished TTIP can be revived.

Given the current state of affairs in the participating countries, it is difficult to see whether it will be completed in the first place, even without the restriction on time. As citizens become increasingly unhappy with the status quo, I believe we have to start challenging the assumptions of globalization, and in particular, trade. Although many economists have agreed that increased trade leads to increased incomes, this has held true only for those at the top of the income ladder. As such, the discontentment with globalization could lead to postponed actions on closing trade deals in the short term, at least for now. Without the introduction of palatable unemployment benefits and wage insurance, I do not expect to see the conclusion of the negotiations of TTIP.

Multinational trade agreements typically take years to negotiate. TTIP negotiations have lasted over 3 years already. The TTIP agreement seems to be having difficulty with those aspects where trade interfaces politics. One such area is the concept of a "Regulatory Cooperating Body." Another, no less contentious but far more prominent at the moment, is that of "investment protection." It seems there are basically three positions here:
1) The American position: Enhance the existing Investor-State Dispute Settlement (ISDS) framework which would provide maximum supra-sovereignty to foreign corporations via specialized commercial arbitration panels.
2) The EU position: Replace the ISDS framework with a new Investment Court System (ICS). This position is identical to the American position in terms of providing maximum supra-sovereignty to foreign corporations, except it accomplishes this with a body of professional judges and provides states the right of appeal. The path from the EU position to desired eventual world investment court via the UN is more straightforward.
3) The Juncker position. This would drop the idea of privileged investment protection for foreign corporations from the TTIP altogether, and place foreign corporations on the same standing as domestic corporations. This position broke an earlier block which allowed the TTIP to move forward, but was quickly abandoned once the negotiation process gained full steam.

Ratification is not required, meaning the question skips out approval/rejection by the 28 member states and Congress. 
Both sides agreed to accelerate their work between negotiating rounds to make significant progress. 
2013 had 3 rounds of talks, 2014 and 2015 had 4 rounds each, considering they have reached the mid-game, that means around 50% of the discussion were complete in 11 talks. On average, each talk represents 4.5% of progress. If 2016 is also expected to have at least 4 rounds, that means 68% of TTIP expected to complete by year end. Aligning with consensus forecast makes my base at 47%.
Negotiation areas mainly consist of tariffs, services and public procurement

That will be challenging, given the technical complexity and the vigorous opposition. It would then have to be approved by the European Parliament and European Trade Ministers. The Ministers usually vote on trade by what is called qualified majority though unanimity might be required - that is both a legal question and a matter of political judgement.
Depending on the legal nature of the final agreement it might also need to be approved by all the EU member states, and Commissioner MalmstrÃ¶m has said that is likely to be necessary. So there is plenty of scope for delays.
And it will need approval by the US Congress. President Obama is struggling unsuccessfully so far - to get Congress to give him what is called Trade Promotion Authority which would make US ratification less difficult. http://www.bbc.com/news/business-32691589

I think what we are seeing here is push-back.  An obvious path of least resistance for TTIP negotiations is to mirror terms already agreed to in TPP. There are provisions in the TPP that McConnell's (R-Tobacco) and Hatch's (R-Pharma) sponsors don't like. They signal that y'all can negotiate all you like, we can't stop you, but we'll stop ratification. (McConnell can do that all by himself so long as he holds the position of Majority Leader.) Arrayed against that is a goodly portion of the rest of American industry, notably Ag and Auto, who are actually at the negotiating table, are reasonably happy with TPP and therefore, presumably, hopeful to see similar terms in TTIP. McConnell and Hatch have effectively signaled that they are putting down markers so that tobacco and pharma have a few more chips to play at the table and see if they can sweeten the deal.

http://www.politico.eu/article/ttip-negotiations-not-even-half-done/
"Negotiations on a massive EU-U.S. trade agreement are not even halfway complete, according to a new European Commission internal assessment, and the lack of progress is raising questions about Brussels’ hopes for concluding the agreement before the end of the Obama administration.
A Commission status report, obtained by POLITICO, shows that on 10 of the 24 chapters of the so-called Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) agreement, the two sides haven’t yet exchanged their positions, much less started to negotiate.
...
Two EU sources involved in the negotiations said Washington’s focus on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), currently being negotiated between the U.S. and several Asian countries (including Japan, South-Korea, Vietnam and Singapore), is causing the delay."

Numerous factors contribute to the current pace of discussions, negotiations and stages of agreement despite calls from EU states to escalate the pace of TTIP interactions.  The 11th round is scheduled for mid October 2015.  No exchange of positions on 10 of 24 chapters of the TTIP, including no negotiations have been made by the US or EU.  The current US Commission Status Report indicate that all position papers from the EU have been sent to the US. France indicates that they have received any serious proposal from the US since 2013.  Current talks are described as 'mid game status.'

Although it has not been officially announced that TTIP negotiations should resume Oct. 19-23 in Miami, all the talk through the media around the agreement may as well be a way to influence the other partner to make concessions in the coming negotiations. As regards France, its influence in EU decision making has been declining in recent years and the remarks of the French State Secretary for Foreign Trade are to be weighed in the context of the next French regional elections in December 2015. The French government and socialist party are really down in the polls and have to redeem themselves in the eye of the French public opinion. They try to show and get support from farmers as the latter feel threatened by an agreement such as TTIP. It is a part of a strategy to diminish the increasing influence of National Front in French politics.
Moreover, on one side, the EU could need the agreement to be completed before the end of 2016, should the "Brexit" take a more credible turn in the wake of the 2017 British referendum. Reaching an agreement on the TTIP would indeed prevent the UK to leave the EU and would probably be one of the best arguments against euro-skeptics in the UK. It would consequently help prevent a EU explosion. One should also remember that the EU constitution was adopted against the public opinion vote in referendums in some major European countries (France, Netherlands).
On the other side, President Barack Obama has been under repeated criticism from Republicans or even from Democrats for his erratic or unclear economic policy/program. It might be for him of importance to leave a trace of relevance in this area and a legacy which would include the creation of the world largest economic market.
All those elements if they come in conjunction could trigger the probabilities the whole way around in very short a time.
